His comments came after news that data involving as many as 50 million Facebook profiles may have been improperly misused.
Speaking at the three-day China Development Forum in Beijing, Apple CEO Tim Cook and IBM CEO Ginni Rometty both called for additional protections for user data.
“If you’re going to use these technologies, you have to tell people you’re doing that, and they should never be surprised,” she said, according to Reuters.
The growth in personal data collected by social media, apps and elsewhere requires new protections for the data itself and for business models, they said.
Several U.S. senators have called for regulations for social media and leaders in the Senate and House have requested Zuckerberg testify before Congress.
Facebook has faced heavy criticism from lawmakers, users, consumer advocates and other tech executives in the wake of the incident.
“(We have to let) people opt in and opt out, and be clear that ownership of the data does belong to the creator,” Rometty said.
